node.title: Normalization of Velocity Profile for Use in Another Model IC
node.bodyText: In order to have an initial guess near the expected final solution, I am solving a problem domain for the velocity profile using fluid properties that provide a more easily converged solution. I would like to then take that solution and normalize it in relation to the maximum velocity. Is there a way for me to then use, the stored solution, normalize it, then provide a multiplier for the expected max velocity based on the actual fluid properties to be used, to then be the initial conditions based on the normalized and multiplied velocity profile?

Hello
yes you can do that.
you ll want to save the variables in an exodus output for example. Then load them into auxiliary variables. Then use an auxkernel (likely ParsedAux) to perform the operations you wanton that field and save the output in another auxvariable.
you can then use this other auxiliary variable for the initialization by loading it from a file again.
Basically you ll need an intermediate input file to perform these operations
If you’re comfortable with MultiApps you could do this in a multi app executed on INITIAL
Guillaume

If my initial solution is solved on a course mesh, Is it possible to interpolate nearest node/element solutions onto a finer mesh using the normalized values determined from the course mesh solution as the initial guess for the fine mesh problem solve?

Sure.
You can look at using a MultiApp for that. Load your solution in the multiapp, then the transfers will do this projection from one mesh to the other for you

node.title: Using mesh generated by gmsh
node.bodyText: I also need a mesh as in discussion and used the same .geo file to generate a mesh. But I have trouble defining BCs by using this mesh.  It always reports an error "boundary top can't be found". I checked mesh using peacock and found top, bottom and so on are blocks not boundaries. So how should I define these as boundaries in gmsh? What is the correspondence between gmsh objects and MOOSE objects? This is really not documented in detail.
The solution is to add a phsical surface, then this physical surface will be in block. The other physical curves are in boundaries.

Hi,
can you share your final .geo file here.

node.title: Numerical oscillation?
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
For the advection-diffusion equation,
I find two versions (compressible and incompressible versions) of advection terms in the advection-diffusion equation.
Now I am trying to test these two cases in MOOSE. The compressible one produces stable results, however, the compressible results are unstable.
Do you have any comments or ideas about this? How to fix this? Thanks.
J

Hello
There are a few other differences here

eq 1 has a source term R which equation 2 does not have
eq 1 can have a spatial dependent diffusion coefficient, in eq 2 it s out of the laplacian
eq 2 has a multiplier on the derivative, which would make the 2 equations very different

We'd need more details to conclude, notably which finite element family and order you are using and which other equations you are solving. Compressible flow is more complex for sure.
Guillaume

Hello
There are a few other differences here

eq 1 has a source term R which equation 2 does not have
eq 1 can have a spatial dependent diffusion coefficient, in eq 2 it s out of the laplacian
eq 2 has a multiplier on the derivative, which would make the 2 equations very different

We'd need more details to conclude, notably which finite element family and order you are using and which other equations you are solving. Compressible flow is more complex for sure.
Guillaume

Dear Guillaume,
please have a look at the updated version of my problem. All the equations are the same except for the different weak forms. The main variable is ‘C'.
[Variables]
  [C]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
[]

you also performed an integration by parts to go from one formulation to the other.
Did you change the boundary condition appropriately?

you also performed an integration by parts to go from one formulation to the other. Did you change the boundary condition appropriately?

The compressible version has stable results, but the incompressible version with DirichletBC and NeumannBC all produce unstable results.
DirichletBC:
  [./left_C]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = C
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 1
  [../]

or
NeumannBC
  [./left_C]
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = C
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 0.1 // or 0.1; or 0.01
  [../]

You need to do more than that. Have a look at the Navier Stokes module finite element treatment of the pressure gradient.
I think the sign should have flipped at the very least.
Is this XY or RZ?

You need to do more than that. Have a look at the Navier Stokes module finite element treatment of the pressure gradient.
I think the sign should have flipped at the very least.
Is this XY or RZ?

This is XY.

You need to do more than that. Have a look at the Navier Stokes module finite element treatment of the pressure gradient.
I think the sign should have flipped at the very least.
Is this XY or RZ?

Thanks a lot, Guillaume. It works after I flip the sign.

I think the sign should have flipped at the very least.
Is this XY or RZ?

Hello Guillaume.
After I performed an integration by parts on the advection term, it will also produce a boundary term? How to set or deal with this boundary term? Should I just ignore it and use the default in MOOSE?
You ll need to create a BC object for it

You ll need to create a BC object for it



Can I just use NeumannBC for the variable C shown in the upper figures instead of creating a BC object for the advection term of variable C?

Or does this Object BC corresponds to the extra term derived from integration by parts? Is it compulsory to use this defined  Object BC  in the input file?

node.title: right/wrong way to read from file in parallel?
node.bodyText: I have a large data file that feeds my AuxKernel (temperature field data, for example). It's a large model and I want to run in parallel. Is there a way I can read the file once and then send all that data to all my CPU's? Right now I've got the file-reading code in initialSetup of my AuxKernel, and it appears to be happening on all CPU's when I run in parallel, which doesn't seem very efficient and creates a bottleneck.

Hello
This is possible.
In your intialSetup(), check for processor_id() == 0 before reading.
Then once you have read on rank 0, use the MPI communicator to broadcast. It's usually a class attribute named _comm.
See the doxygen for that class
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/timpi/classlibMesh_1_1Parallel_1_1Communicator.html
You ll like want something like "broadcast" for a rank 0 to all others communication.
Guillaume

note that depending on your system, distributing the file and reading only the part that matters to each rank can be a faster solution. It's likely that a hybrid solution, with file reading in some rank then communication to groups of other ranks is the fastest.
Thanks, I'll look into that. What kinds of data are supported? Can I just distribute basic types like floats and strings or can I make a std::map and broadcast that?
Are there any (simple) examples of this? If process 0 broadcasts some data, how do other processes receive it?
There's a broadcast of some tuple in MultiAppTransfer.C to communicate the multiapp coord transform
looks like map_broadcast doesn't take a std::map but instead a Map type. Any idea how one converts to/from that? Also the function takes a few other arguments which I can't figure out.

Took a guess at the other arguments (0 and true) and the compiler complains that the map_broadcast function is private. I do see a few overloaded versions of the function in the doxygen, but I can't tell the difference. They all take a Map, unsigned int, and bool.

you call broadcast and under the hood it links to map_broadcast.
The broadcast call should be very simple
_comm.broadcast(the thing)
oh, thanks for pointing that out
ok, new error. The compiler doesn't seem to like my map, which is std::map<std::vector<Real>, const Function *>. (changing the map's return type to a Real does compile though, so we're getting close)

node.title: Error with ADComputeFiniteStrain
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSEer,
When I use the module [ADComputeFiniteStrain], the following error comes up. I checked the mesh and don't think the elements are heavily distorted, the strain level is low actually. Any suggestions/comments to avoid this error? Thanks.
Cannot take square root of a number less than or equal to zero in the calculation of C1 for the Rashid approximation for the rotation tensor. This zero or negative number may occur when elements become heavily distorted. Cannot take square root of a number less than or equal to zero in the calculation of C3_test for the Rashid approximation for the rotation tensor. This zero or negative number may occur when elements become heavily distorted.

Hello
Did the solve finish after this?
You need to examine the output after this warning to see distortion. There is a FAILED execution flag for output you can use
The solution for this is usually to take smaller time steps, or if it's happening near a Dirichlet boundary condition, to not pre-set the dirichlet BCs.
Guillaume

The solve stops calculation until reach the time limit, and the distortion is not big at all. And it's not happening near a Dirichlet B.C., I'll try with a smaller dt.
Here is the error output message.
err.log

does it make the first time step?
The elements seem very inverted from the libmesh output in the log

No, it occurs in the middle fo the calculation.
The mesh type is tetrahedron, does it matter?
Tets should be fine.

node.title: Scalar product of two vectors in kernel
node.bodyText: I wonder how to make scalar product of two vectors when writing a kernel, like u=v.*w, while all of u, v, w are vectors, or specifically, ADRealVectorValue. Is there a related documentation explaining this, or other related operations?

You can have a look at the doxygen for the base class of RealVectorValue
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/classlibMesh_1_1VectorValue.html
and if you cant find that there, this is a very simple for loop
What you described is not a scalar product btw.

node.title: VectorVariable Gradient at a Point
node.bodyText: Is there a way to get a VectorVariable gradient at a point? Just looking for a function that I can call within the VectorNodalBC class.

@maxnezdyur  I have done something similar here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/auxkernels/ArrayDirectionalDerivative.C
In my case it is a directional derivative, but you can simply use the gradient,
the variable that express the gradient is:
_grad_variable_qp
Trust this helps,
Nicolò
are you thinking of coupledGradient from the coupleable interface ?

So when using the VectorNodalBC class, I need to find the gradient at a location within the element. Do you know how coupledGradient works when you are on a node? I may be overthinking this and it would work. I finally found this in system.h, it has a few functions for point_gradient, but I don't know if it works for vector variables.

so coupledVectorGradient then for vector variables most likely.
and this is a nodal vector variable right? a Lagrange_vec ?

Yes this is Lagrange_vec.
So coupledVectorGradient calls var->gradSln() which calls _element_data->gradSln(Moose::Current). I may be misunderstanding this but when using the VectorNodalBC, which element gradient will it be giving? A node may be connected to multiple elements with different gradients.

yep this doesnt look right.
The coupleable interface has nodal value routines. (coupledNodalValue for example)
I think you may need to build the gradient ones because I dont see them
I probably will try to build version of point_gradient that can work with Lagrange_vec.

For a Lagrange variable, the derivative is not continuous on nodes is it?
This is typically why these routines are missing. For other higher order types we could have been better defined
Yes I agree. That's why I am trying to find the gradient at a point that I know is within an element so it should be better defined.

I do think that point_gradient is the best (maybe only) API to use here. If it doesn't work yet for vector finite element types ... actually yea as I'm typing this I realize that it most certainly won't work. Let me think a little bit more
FEMContext is a good way to go if you already have one in use for a quadrature loop; I don't think it offers anything over the lower-level APIs if you just need a one-off.

node.title: PETSC ERROR: Out of memory
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am facing out of memory problem after 62 seconds of simulation though i think i asked for maximum memory. Please give your suggestions on it.
Preconditioning and Executioner used -
[Preconditioning]                
  [./SMP]                        
    type = SMP                   
    full = true                  
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_grmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
    petsc_options_value = 'asm      121                  preonly       lu           4'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient              
  scheme = bdf2                 
  verbose = True                
  solve_type ='PJFNK'           
                                                       
  l_max_its = 50
  l_tol = 1e-5
  nl_max_its = 50
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-6
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm      31                  preonly      lu          4'
                        
  dt=0.01               
  end_time = 400       
  line_search = 'none'
[]

My job submission allocation request is :
#!/bin/bash
#PBS -l walltime=168:00:00,select=4:ncpus=32:mpiprocs=32:mem=180gb
#PBS -N Zn_MOOSE
#PBS -A st-mponga1-1
#PBS -o output.txt
#PBS -e error.txt

################################################################################

module load gcc/9.4.0            
module load cmake/3.20.3
module load git/2.31.1
module load python/3.8.10
module load openmpi/4.1.1-cuda11-3

conda activate moose

cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR

mpiexec -n 128 /home/galibubc/scratch/musanna/MOOSE/project/dendrite__zn/dendrite__zn-opt -i input.i>log.txt

Hello,
I didn't understand "how to tighten the convergence criteria." Can you please give some suggestion. Also, how might this cause petse memory error?
No the job was scheduled for 168 hours but run less that  68 hours. I don't explicitly asked for RAM in my scheduler. Is it the cause that the output file size is too big? Any way to reduce the output file size?
Thanks

To tighten the convergence criteria, you can make the numbers in nl_abs_tol, nl_rel_tol smaller
It's unlikely to cause a petsc error, though it's happened before that petsc reports running out of memory when it s really diverging
You can reduce the output file size by reducing the number of fields output (use show=' ' in Exodus block)
It's unlikely to be the cause
You also can fix:

petsc options are passed twice, once in Preconditioning once in Executioner. You only need that once
you have 2 exodus outputs, one called other with a large interval, and another one every time step

Thanks. Can you please explain how to use show in Exodus block to specify which field output i want?
For some reason, block arrays i defined is not showing in paraview? How can i get these field output?
This isnt right. They should show up. Maybe it didnt "Apply" the settings on the middle left property.

node.title: Generate Mesh with different material blocks
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
Which internal mesh generator would be the most suitable for me?
I am looking to generate simple meshes at first with two different materials, which would be similar to a cylindrical pipe with steel on the outside and another material inside.
This would be a first tests before I go on to more "advanced" geometries.
Is it possible to do this with something like GeneratedMesh directly in MOOSE or should I use something else like GMSH?
Thanks!

Hello
Material blocks are subdomains or blocks in MOOSE.
Many generators allow for this feature. I think GeneratedMeshGenerator allows it, if not CartesianMeshGenerator is a good option
Guillaume

The CartesianMeshGenerator worked to define the materials to subdomains.
However, now I am running into a new problem:
ERROR
Material properties must be retrieved during object construction. This is a code problem.
Does this also have to do with the generated mesh and the assignment of materials and its properties during the generation of the mesh?

No this seems independent. Do you mind sharing your input file here?
Are you using a moose module or an app?

The simulation uses quite alot of custom built kernels, but I can also include them in the repository.
https://github.com/mfitzka/phoenixpublic
The input file is called SimpleTestCartesian.i

ok then in one of the custom-made objects (or kernels) you must have something like getMaterialProperty outside of the constructor. This will not work, you need to modify the code to make it retrieve a reference to the material property during the construction of the kernel.
An example:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/kernels/ADMatReaction.C
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/include/kernels/ADMatReaction.h
look at the _reaction_rate material property

I added the custom kernels used in the application in the repository.
At first glance, I cant seem to find the problem, as some of them are original MOOSE code and in all of the others the getMaterialProperty command should be inside the constructor.
Am I overlooking something?

I dont see any kernels in the repo.
Is it this one?
https://github.com/mfitzka/phoenixpublic

Sorry for the confusion, I forgot to confirm the uploads.
All of them can now be found in the folder "kernels".

Simply moving it to the constructor did not work, as i got several errors.
(error expected "{" before "_density")
I guess I must also change the syntax to match the others, but with for example
_density(getMaterialProperty("density")), I also get errors.
Are there some tutorials regarding coding this, as I am completely new to C++?

just do this:
    CoupledCureTimeDerivative::CoupledCureTimeDerivative(const InputParameters & parameters) :
        Kernel(parameters),
    _density(&getMaterialProperty<Real>("density")),
    _Hr(&getMaterialProperty<Real>("Hr")),
	_v_dot(coupledDot("v")),
	 _dv_dot(coupledDotDu("v")),
        _v_var(coupled("v"))
    {}

I tried this, but then I get the error:
multiple initializations given for "CoupledCureTimeDerivative::_density"
and the same for _Hr.
Should I remove the _density(NULL), and _Hr(NULL), lines?
